title: Help-Seeking and Supporting Others
subject: Health and Physical Education
description: This topic explores strategies for seeking help for mental health concerns and how to support others who may be struggling. Students learn to identify trusted adults and professional support services, overcome barriers to help-seeking, recognise warning signs in peers, and develop skills for providing appropriate support while knowing when to involve adults.

curriculumDescriptions.VC2HP8P01: Examine the impact of changes and transitions, and devise strategies to support themselves and others through these times
curriculumDescriptions.VC2HP8P03: Investigate and apply strategies to enhance their own and others' health, safety and wellbeing

contentSections.content:
When you feel sad, worried, or scared, there are people who can help you. These are called trusted adults.

Trusted adults at home:
• Mum or Dad
• Grandparents
• Older brothers or sisters
• Aunts and uncles

Trusted adults at school:
• Teachers
• School counsellor
• Principal
• Coaches

Other helpers:
• Doctors
• Police officers
• Lifeguards

A trusted adult is someone who:
• Listens to you
• Keeps you safe
• Helps when you ask
• Is kind to you

Asking for help is a smart thing to do. Here are some ways to ask:

Words you can say:
• 'I need help'
• 'Can you help me?'
• 'I feel sad/worried/scared'
• 'Something is wrong'

When to ask for help:
• When you feel very sad
• When you feel scared
• When someone hurts you
• When you don't know what to do
• When worries won't go away

Remember:
• It's okay to ask for help
• Everyone needs help sometimes
• Asking for help is brave
• Keep asking until someone listens

You can help your friends when they feel sad. Here's how to be a good friend:

Things you can do:
• Sit with them
• Ask 'Are you okay?'
• Listen to them talk
• Be kind
• Play with them

Things you can say:
• 'I'm here for you'
• 'Do you want to talk?'
• 'Let's tell a teacher'
• 'It will be okay'

Important:
• If a friend is very sad or hurt, tell an adult
• You don't have to fix everything
• Being there is helping

contentSections.content:
A support network is made up of the people who care about you and can help when you need it. Everyone should have people they can turn to.

People in your support network might include:
• Parents or carers
• Other family members
• Teachers and school counsellors
• Coaches or group leaders
• Family friends
• Friends you trust

A good support person:
• Listens without judging you
• Keeps things private when needed
• Gives helpful advice
• Makes you feel safe
• Respects your feelings

You might need different people for different problems:
• Family problems → trusted family member or counsellor
• School problems → teacher or parent
• Friend problems → parent, teacher, or other trusted adult
• Health worries → parent or doctor

Try to have at least 3-5 trusted adults you can turn to. If one person isn't available, you can ask another.

Sometimes it's hard to know when to ask for help. Here are signs that you or a friend might need support:

Signs in yourself:
• Feeling sad, worried, or scared for a long time
• Not enjoying things you usually like
• Having trouble sleeping or eating
• Feeling alone or left out
• Worrying that won't stop
• Feeling angry a lot
• Having problems at school

Signs in a friend:
• They seem sad or quiet
• They're not hanging out with friends
• They've stopped doing activities they liked
• They're more angry or upset than usual
• They talk about feeling hopeless
• Their school work has changed
• They're not looking after themselves

When to get help straight away:
• If someone talks about hurting themselves
• If someone is in danger
• If you feel very unsafe

Remember: asking for help early is better than waiting until things get worse.

Asking for help can feel hard, but it's one of the bravest things you can do.

Barriers to asking for help:
• Feeling embarrassed
• Worried about what others will think
• Not sure who to ask
• Thinking the problem isn't big enough
• Not knowing what to say

Ways to overcome barriers:
• Remember that everyone needs help sometimes
• Remind yourself that asking for help is brave, not weak
• Write down what you want to say first
• Choose a good time to talk
• Start with someone you feel comfortable with

How to ask for help:
• Find a quiet, private place
• Say how you're feeling: 'I've been feeling really worried...'
• Explain what's happening: 'Something has been bothering me...'
• Ask for what you need: 'Can you help me with...?'

If the first person doesn't help:
• Try asking someone else
• Keep trying until someone listens
• It's not your fault if someone doesn't help

You can help friends who are struggling, but it's also important to know your limits.

How to support a friend:
• Notice when they seem different or upset
• Ask if they're okay in a private moment
• Listen without interrupting or judging
• Show you care by being there for them
• Encourage them to talk to an adult
• Include them in activities

Things you can say:
• 'I've noticed you seem sad. Is everything okay?'
• 'I'm here if you want to talk'
• 'That sounds really hard'
• 'It's not your fault'
• 'Have you thought about talking to [trusted adult]?'

Important things to remember:
• You don't have to fix their problems
• It's okay to tell an adult if you're worried
• You should never promise to keep a secret if someone is unsafe
• Look after yourself too
• If you're worried about a friend, tell a trusted adult

When to tell an adult:
• If your friend talks about hurting themselves
• If they are in danger
• If the problem is too big for you to handle
• If you're worried about them

contentSections.content:
Help-seeking is a protective factor for mental health. It involves recognising when you need support, deciding to seek help, and taking action to get it. Research shows that young people who seek help when they need it have better mental health outcomes.

The help-seeking process includes:
1. Recognising that there is a problem or challenge
2. Believing that the problem is significant enough to warrant help
3. Deciding that seeking help is an appropriate response
4. Having the knowledge and ability to access help
5. Taking action to seek help

Types of help-seeking:
• Formal help-seeking: Accessing professional services such as counsellors, psychologists, doctors, or helplines
• Informal help-seeking: Turning to family, friends, teachers, or other trusted adults
• Self-help: Using strategies, resources, or information independently

When to seek help:
• When feelings of sadness, anxiety, or anger persist for an extended period
• When emotions are affecting daily life, relationships, or schoolwork
• When coping strategies aren't working
• When thoughts of self-harm occur (seek help immediately)
• When experiencing significant life changes or challenges
• When worrying thoughts won't go away

Many young people face barriers that prevent them from seeking help when they need it. Understanding these barriers is the first step to overcoming them.

Personal barriers:
• Not recognising that there is a problem
• Believing the problem isn't serious enough
• Wanting to handle things independently
• Fear of what others might think (stigma)
• Embarrassment or shame about the problem
• Fear of negative consequences (e.g., parents finding out)
• Not knowing how to express what's wrong
• Previous negative experiences with help-seeking

Social barriers:
• Stigma around mental health in the community
• Cultural beliefs about help-seeking
• Peer pressure to appear 'fine' or 'strong'
• Concerns about confidentiality
• Lack of supportive relationships

Structural barriers:
• Not knowing where to get help
• Lack of accessible services
• Cost of professional services
• Limited time or opportunity to access help

Strategies to overcome barriers:
• Education about mental health to reduce stigma
• Knowing what services are available and how to access them
• Building trusting relationships with potential support people
• Practising help-seeking language and skills
• Starting with informal support before formal help
• Using technology-based support when face-to-face feels too difficult

A strong support network is essential for maintaining mental health and wellbeing. It provides a safety net during challenging times and resources for everyday support.

Components of an effective support network:

1. Family members: Parents, siblings, grandparents, or other relatives who know you well and care about your wellbeing

2. Friends: Peers who provide companionship, understanding, and mutual support

3. School personnel: Teachers, school counsellors, wellbeing staff, coaches, and other trusted adults at school

4. Community connections: Leaders of clubs, sports, or community groups, religious leaders, or other trusted community members

5. Professional support: Counsellors, psychologists, doctors, and helpline services

Qualities of good support people:
• They listen without judging
• They respect your privacy (confidentiality)
• They validate your feelings
• They offer helpful perspectives
• They know when to involve others
• They're available when you need them

Strategies for building your network:
• Identify at least five trusted people you could turn to
• Consider who can help with different types of problems
• Maintain these relationships through regular contact
• Be a supportive person for others too
• Know how to access professional support if needed

Knowing how to ask for help is a valuable life skill. The following strategies can make help-seeking more effective.

Preparing to seek help:
• Choose the right person for your specific need
• Find a good time and private place to talk
• Think about what you want to say beforehand
• Write down key points if it helps
• Be prepared that you might need to try more than once

Starting the conversation:
• 'I need to talk to you about something important'
• 'I've been going through a tough time and could use some help'
• 'Something's been bothering me and I'm not sure what to do'
• 'I'm worried about [specific issue] and need some advice'

During the conversation:
• Be honest about how you're feeling
• Give specific examples if you can
• Say what kind of help you're looking for
• Ask questions if you don't understand
• It's okay to show emotion

If the first person doesn't help:
• Don't give up - try someone else
• Consider a different type of support (e.g., helpline)
• Remember it's not your fault if someone doesn't respond well
• Keep trying until you get the help you need

Support services available:
• School counsellors and wellbeing teams
• Kids Helpline: 1800 55 1800 (available 24/7)
• Headspace: for young people's mental health
• eheadspace: online and phone support
• Beyond Blue: 1300 22 4636
• Lifeline: 13 11 14 (crisis support)

Young people often turn to their friends first when they're struggling. Knowing how to support friends while also recognising your own limits is an important skill.

Recognising when a friend might need support:
• Changes in mood or behaviour
• Withdrawal from friends or activities
• Declining academic performance
• Changes in eating or sleeping patterns
• Increased irritability or aggression
• Talking about hopelessness or having no future
• Risk-taking behaviour
• Expressing thoughts of self-harm

How to offer support:
• Choose a private, comfortable place to talk
• Start with an observation: 'I've noticed you've seemed a bit down lately'
• Use open questions: 'How are you really going?'
• Listen actively without interrupting
• Show empathy: 'That sounds really hard'
• Avoid judgement or giving too much advice
• Encourage them to talk to a trusted adult
• Offer to go with them if they want support

Active listening skills:
• Give full attention (put away phone)
• Use body language that shows you're listening
• Reflect back what they've said
• Ask clarifying questions
• Don't rush to fix or give advice

Knowing your limits:
• You can support a friend but you can't be their therapist
• It's not your responsibility to 'fix' them
• It's okay to feel worried or overwhelmed
• You need to look after yourself too

When to involve an adult:
• If a friend talks about hurting themselves or suicide
• If they are in immediate danger
• If the situation is beyond what you can handle
• If you're very worried about them
• It's always okay to tell an adult, even if your friend asked you not to - safety comes first

remember.stem: What is the difference between formal and informal support?

options.text: Formal support is from professionals, informal support is from family and friends
options.feedback: Correct! Formal support comes from trained professionals like counsellors and psychologists, while informal support comes from family, friends, and other trusted people in your life.

options.text: Formal support requires an appointment, informal support doesn't
options.feedback: While appointments are often needed for formal support, this isn't the main distinction. The key difference is who provides the support.

options.text: Formal support is free, informal support costs money
options.feedback: This is incorrect. Many formal support services do cost money, while informal support from friends and family is typically free.

options.text: Formal support is for adults only, informal support is for young people
options.feedback: Both types of support are available to people of all ages. The distinction is about who provides the support, not who receives it.

remember.stem: Which of the following is an example of active listening?

options.text: Checking your phone while your friend talks
options.feedback: Looking at your phone shows you're not fully focused on the conversation, which is the opposite of active listening.

options.text: Giving advice before your friend finishes speaking
options.feedback: Interrupting with advice doesn't allow your friend to fully express themselves and isn't active listening.

options.text: Reflecting back what your friend has said to show understanding
options.feedback: That's right! Reflecting back shows you're paying attention and helps confirm your understanding of what they've shared.

options.text: Changing the subject to something more positive
options.feedback: Changing the subject dismisses your friend's feelings rather than showing you're listening to them.

relational.stem: Explain how barriers to help-seeking are connected to the importance of building strong support networks.
relational.modelResponse: Barriers to help-seeking and support networks are closely connected. When people face barriers like stigma, embarrassment, or not knowing where to go, having a strong support network provides more options to overcome these obstacles. For example, if someone is too embarrassed to see a counsellor, they might first talk to a trusted friend or family member who can help them take that step. A diverse support network means there's always someone who might feel approachable, reducing the impact of personal barriers. Additionally, supportive relationships help normalise help-seeking, which can reduce stigma over time.
relational.rubric: Explains the relationship between barriers and support networks with clear reasoning and examples

extendedAbstract.stem: How might improving help-seeking attitudes and behaviours among young people contribute to better mental health outcomes across the whole community?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Improving help-seeking among young people creates positive ripple effects across the entire community. When young people learn to seek help early, problems are addressed before they become severe, reducing the long-term burden on mental health services. Young people who are comfortable with help-seeking grow into adults who model these behaviours, gradually shifting cultural norms away from stigma. As more people openly discuss mental health, it becomes normalised, encouraging others who might be struggling to reach out. Schools and families that support help-seeking create environments where early intervention is possible. Over time, this creates a community where mental health is treated like physical health - where seeking help is seen as responsible self-care rather than a sign of weakness. This cultural shift can lead to reduced rates of severe mental illness, better support systems, and improved wellbeing for everyone.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Generalises help-seeking concepts to community-level mental health outcomes with sophisticated reasoning

vocabularyTerms.definition: The process of actively looking for and obtaining help, encompassing problem recognition, belief that help is needed and available, and taking action to access support
The conditions in which people are born, grow, live, work, and age that affect mental health outcomes, including access to support and services

contentSections.content:
Understanding why people do or don't seek help requires examining the psychological, social, and cultural factors that influence this behaviour.

Theoretical models of help-seeking:

The Health Belief Model suggests people seek help when they:
• Perceive they are susceptible to a problem
• Believe the problem is serious
• See more benefits than barriers in seeking help
• Have cues that trigger action
• Feel confident in their ability to seek help (self-efficacy)

The Theory of Planned Behaviour emphasises:
• Attitudes toward help-seeking (positive or negative views)
• Subjective norms (what others think about help-seeking)
• Perceived behavioural control (belief in ability to access help)

Developmental considerations for adolescents:
• Increasing desire for autonomy and privacy
• Greater influence of peer opinions
• Developing sense of identity and self-concept
• Brain development affecting risk assessment and decision-making
• Transition from relying on parents to broader networks

Gender differences in help-seeking:
• Research shows males are often less likely to seek help
• Societal expectations around masculinity can create barriers
• Females may be more likely to seek informal support first
• Understanding these patterns helps in developing targeted strategies

Cultural influences:
• Different cultures have varying attitudes toward mental health
• Collectivist cultures may prioritise family involvement
• Stigma levels vary across cultural groups
• Culturally appropriate services are essential for effective help-seeking

Beyond personal barriers, systemic factors significantly impact access to mental health support. Understanding these helps in advocating for better services.

Structural barriers in the Australian context:
• Geographic limitations (rural and remote access)
• Wait times for services
• Cost of private services
• Limited bulk-billing options
• Shortage of mental health professionals
• Gaps in youth-specific services

Social determinants affecting help-seeking:
• Socioeconomic status and financial resources
• Cultural background and language barriers
• Family attitudes toward mental health
• Community resources and supports
• Experiences of discrimination or marginalisation
• Housing stability and basic needs security

Intersectionality:
People with multiple marginalised identities may face compounded barriers. For example:
• An Indigenous young person in a rural area faces both geographic and cultural barriers
• A young person from a migrant background with limited English may struggle to access appropriate services
• LGBTQIA+ young people may worry about discrimination from service providers

Addressing systemic barriers:
• School-based services reduce access barriers
• Telehealth and online services increase reach
• Youth-friendly services designed with young people's input
• Culturally safe services with diverse staff
• Peer support programs as early intervention
• Advocacy for policy changes and increased funding

Building and utilising support networks effectively requires strategic thinking about different types of support for different needs.

Types of social support:
1. Emotional support: Empathy, love, trust, and caring
2. Instrumental support: Practical help and assistance
3. Informational support: Advice, guidance, and information
4. Appraisal support: Feedback and affirmation

Strategic network building:
• Diversity: Include people with different strengths and perspectives
• Accessibility: Ensure support is available when needed
• Reciprocity: Give as well as receive support
• Depth: Develop some relationships that allow vulnerability
• Breadth: Maintain connections across different contexts

The support network ecosystem:

Immediate support (daily/weekly contact):
• Close friends
• Family members
• Peers at school

Secondary support (regular contact):
• Teachers and mentors
• Extended family
• Coaches and group leaders

Professional support (as needed):
• School counsellors
• GPs and healthcare providers
• Psychologists and counsellors
• Crisis services

Community support (broader context):
• Youth organisations
• Religious or cultural groups
• Online communities (with appropriate safety awareness)

Maintaining network health:
• Regular check-ins with support people
• Expressing gratitude and appreciation
• Being available to support others
• Updating your network as life changes
• Addressing conflicts constructively

Advanced help-seeking skills involve understanding different communication approaches and adapting to various contexts.

Assertive communication in help-seeking:
• Clearly stating your needs without aggression or passivity
• Using 'I' statements to express feelings
• Being specific about what kind of help you want
• Respectfully persisting if not initially successful

Navigating difficult conversations:

With parents/carers:
• Choose a calm moment
• Be direct but respectful
• Explain how they can help
• Be prepared for their emotional reactions
• Suggest resources they could learn from

With professionals:
• Prepare key points in advance
• Be honest about symptoms and experiences
• Ask questions if you don't understand
• Advocate for your needs and preferences
• Provide feedback about what is or isn't working

With teachers/school staff:
• Request a private conversation
• Explain the impact on your schoolwork if relevant
• Ask about available support options
• Discuss any accommodations that might help

Using technology for help-seeking:
• Online counselling and telehealth services
• Mental health apps for self-management
• Crisis text lines and chat services
• Online peer support communities (with safety awareness)

Self-advocacy in mental health:
• Understanding your rights as a service user
• Requesting different services if current approach isn't working
• Involving a support person in appointments if helpful
• Participating in treatment decisions
• Providing feedback to improve services

Young people often act as first responders for their peers. Understanding how to do this effectively and safely is crucial.

The evidence base for peer support:
• Research shows peers are often the first point of contact
• Peer support can reduce stigma and encourage professional help-seeking
• Peer relationships provide unique benefits (shared experiences, relatability)
• Effective peer support is associated with better outcomes

Advanced peer support techniques:

Motivational approaches:
• Express empathy without judgement
• Develop discrepancy (help them see the gap between current and desired state)
• Roll with resistance (don't argue or force)
• Support self-efficacy (believe in their ability to change)

Crisis response:
• Stay calm and be present
• Listen without trying to immediately fix
• Avoid minimising or dismissing their experience
• Don't promise to keep secrets about safety issues
• Know crisis resources and when to use them
• Get adult help for serious concerns

Self-harm and suicide conversations:
• It's okay to ask directly about self-harm or suicidal thoughts
• Asking does not plant the idea or increase risk
• Take all expressions of self-harm seriously
• Always involve an adult for safety concerns
• Follow up and continue to show care

Boundaries in peer support:
• You are not a therapist and shouldn't try to be
• It's okay to say 'I don't know how to help with this'
• Encouraging professional help is appropriate
• You need to look after your own mental health
• Seek support for yourself if peer support becomes overwhelming

Postvention and supporting others after crisis:
• Be present and patient
• Avoid asking for details about what happened
• Check in regularly over time
• Watch for warning signs in yourself and others
• Know that grief and recovery aren't linear

relational.stem: Explain how mental health literacy is connected to overcoming barriers to help-seeking.
relational.modelResponse: Mental health literacy and help-seeking barriers are closely connected. When people have good mental health literacy, they can recognise when they or others are experiencing problems, which addresses the barrier of not recognising that help is needed. Understanding that mental health problems are common and treatable helps reduce stigma, which is a major barrier. Knowledge of what services exist and how to access them addresses informational barriers. Mental health literacy also builds confidence in talking about mental health and knowing what to expect from treatment, which reduces fear and uncertainty. Therefore, improving mental health literacy directly attacks multiple barriers at once.
relational.rubric: Explains the relationship with clear reasoning showing how literacy addresses multiple barriers

extendedAbstract.stem: How might the concept of community-wide mental health promotion, including peer support initiatives, change our approach to mental health from a treatment model to a prevention model?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Moving from treatment to prevention through community-wide mental health promotion represents a fundamental shift in approach. Traditional treatment models wait for problems to develop and then intervene, which is reactive and reaches people only after they're struggling. A prevention model with peer support and mental health promotion creates environments where problems are less likely to develop and are addressed early when they do. This shift involves: building mental health literacy so everyone can recognise early signs; training peer supporters to provide immediate, accessible first response; creating cultures where help-seeking is normalised; addressing social determinants that contribute to poor mental health; and empowering communities to support their own wellbeing. The implications are significant: reduced demand on specialist services, better outcomes through early intervention, decreased stigma, and improved community resilience. However, this requires investment in prevention and a recognition that mental health is a community responsibility, not just an individual one.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Synthesises concepts to propose a paradigm shift with sophisticated reasoning about implications

contentSections.content:
Understanding help-seeking requires examining the research literature and how it informs practice and policy.

Key research findings on adolescent help-seeking:

Prevalence of mental health problems:
• Approximately 1 in 7 Australian young people experience a mental health condition
• Average delay between onset of symptoms and treatment is 8-10 years
• Young people are the least likely age group to seek professional help
• Most young people with mental health problems do not access services

Factors associated with help-seeking:
• Higher mental health literacy predicts greater help-seeking
• Perceived stigma significantly reduces help-seeking
• Previous positive experiences increase future help-seeking
• Social support facilitates access to professional help
• Gender, culture, and socioeconomic factors all influence patterns

Effective interventions to promote help-seeking:
• Gatekeeper training programs (e.g., Mental Health First Aid)
• School-based mental health literacy programs
• Youth-friendly service models
• Digital mental health interventions
• Peer support and peer education programs
• Reducing structural barriers (cost, access, wait times)

Gaps in the research:
• Limited studies on diverse populations
• Need for more longitudinal research
• Better understanding of what prevents help-seeking at each stage
• Evaluation of digital and innovative approaches
• Implementation research on scaling effective programs

contentSections.sectionTitle: Analysing Mental Health Policy and Systems
contentSections.content:
Mental health services operate within complex policy and funding environments that significantly impact access and outcomes.

Australian mental health system structure:

Federal government:
• Medicare-funded psychology and psychiatry
• National Mental Health Strategy
• Headspace and other national programs
• Mental health reform initiatives

State/Territory governments:
• Public mental health services
• School mental health programs
• Community mental health teams
• Emergency and crisis services

Private sector:
• Private psychologists and psychiatrists
• Private hospitals
• Employee assistance programs

Community sector:
• Not-for-profit organisations
• Helplines and online services
• Peer support organisations

Critical analysis of current system:

Strengths:
• Better Access program improves affordability for some
• Headspace provides youth-specific services
• Growing recognition of prevention and early intervention
• Increasing online and telehealth options

Weaknesses:
• Fragmented system with poor coordination
• Gaps between services creating 'missing middle'
• Insufficient funding for acute services
• Workforce shortages
• Inequitable access for rural, remote, and marginalised populations
• Over-reliance on crisis response rather than prevention

Equity analysis:
• Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people face significant barriers
• Cultural and linguistic diversity not well addressed
• LGBTQIA+ young people need affirming services
• Rural and remote access remains problematic
• Socioeconomic disadvantage limits options

Effective approaches to improving help-seeking require interventions at multiple levels of the social ecology.

Social ecological model applied to help-seeking:

1. Individual level:
• Mental health literacy education
• Building self-efficacy for help-seeking
• Developing communication skills
• Addressing personal beliefs and attitudes

2. Interpersonal level:
• Support network development
• Peer support training
• Family mental health education
• Relationship skill building

3. Community level:
• School-wide mental health promotion
• Community awareness campaigns
• Youth-friendly service development
• Local support networks

4. Institutional level:
• School mental health policies
• Workplace mental health programs
• Healthcare system improvements
• Training for staff who work with young people

5. Policy level:
• Funding for mental health services
• National mental health strategies
• Anti-stigma legislation
• Integration of mental health into broader policy

Prevention framework:

Universal prevention:
• Applies to everyone
• Mental health education in schools
• Public awareness campaigns
• Creating supportive environments

Selective prevention:
• Targets at-risk groups
• Programs for children of parents with mental illness
• Support for young people experiencing life transitions
• Culturally specific programs

Indicated prevention:
• Targets those showing early signs
• Early intervention programs
• School counselling services
• Brief interventions in primary care

Creating effective help-seeking interventions requires applying research evidence, theoretical frameworks, and implementation science principles.

Intervention design process:

1. Needs assessment:
• What barriers exist in this specific context?
• What resources and strengths are present?
• What do community members identify as priorities?
• What does the evidence say about effective approaches?

2. Theory-informed design:
• Apply behavioural theories (Health Belief Model, Theory of Planned Behaviour)
• Use the social ecological model to target multiple levels
• Incorporate co-design with young people
• Consider cultural and contextual factors

3. Evidence-based components:
• Mental health literacy content
• Stigma reduction strategies
• Skills training (communication, help-seeking, peer support)
• Information about services and how to access them
• Ongoing support and follow-up

4. Implementation considerations:
• Who will deliver the intervention?
• What training and resources are needed?
• How will fidelity be maintained?
• What are potential barriers to implementation?

5. Evaluation design:
• Process evaluation (was it delivered as planned?)
• Outcome evaluation (did it achieve its goals?)
• Cost-effectiveness analysis
• Sustainability planning

Example: School-based intervention design:

Components:
• Universal mental health curriculum
• Trained peer supporters
• Clear referral pathways
• Parent education component
• Staff professional development
• Partnership with local services

Implementation:
• Embed in existing structures
• Champion teachers to lead
• Student leadership involvement
• Regular review and adaptation

Supporting mental health and promoting help-seeking involves complex ethical considerations that require careful attention.

Ethical principles in mental health support:

1. Autonomy:
• Respecting young people's right to make decisions
• Providing information without coercion
• Supporting informed consent
• Recognising developing capacity

2. Beneficence and non-maleficence:
• Acting in the person's best interest
• Avoiding actions that could cause harm
• Balancing benefits and risks of interventions
• Considering unintended consequences

3. Justice:
• Equitable access to support and services
• Addressing systemic disadvantage
• Fair allocation of resources
• Advocating for vulnerable groups

4. Confidentiality and its limits:
• Respecting privacy of information shared
• Clear communication about limits
• Duty of care when safety is at risk
• Navigating peer support and confidentiality

Ethical dilemmas in practice:
• When to break confidentiality for safety
• Balancing autonomy with duty of care
• Respecting cultural practices that may conflict with mainstream approaches
• Resource allocation decisions
• Gatekeeping and ensuring appropriate referrals

Emerging trends and future directions:

1. Digital mental health:
• Apps and online platforms for self-help and therapy
• Artificial intelligence in mental health support
• Social media for mental health promotion
• Digital service delivery and telehealth

2. Youth participation:
• Young people as co-designers of services
• Youth advisory boards and governance
• Peer workforce development
• Youth-led advocacy and campaigns

3. System transformation:
• Integration of services
• Shift from acute to prevention focus
• Community-based and recovery-oriented models
• Addressing social determinants

4. Research priorities:
• Implementation science
• Personalised interventions
• Long-term outcomes
• Cost-effectiveness

multistructural.modelResponse: A comprehensive school-based intervention should include: 1) A universal mental health curriculum that builds mental health literacy for all students; 2) A trained peer support program where selected students are equipped to provide first-level support; 3) Clear referral pathways connecting students to school counsellors and external services; and 4) Staff professional development to ensure teachers can recognise signs and respond appropriately.

relational.stem: Explain how individual-level interventions and system-level changes interact to improve help-seeking outcomes.
relational.modelResponse: Individual and system-level interventions work together synergistically. Individual interventions like mental health literacy education help people recognise problems and know how to seek help. However, if services are inaccessible due to cost, wait times, or geographic barriers, individuals can't act on their knowledge. System-level changes address these structural barriers, making services available when people are ready to access them. Similarly, when services are improved but individuals don't know about them or fear stigma, the services remain underutilised. The most effective approach addresses both levels: building individual capacity while simultaneously removing structural barriers, so that increased readiness to seek help is matched by accessible, appropriate services.
relational.rubric: Explains the bidirectional relationship with clear reasoning about how both levels are necessary

extendedAbstract.stem: How might a fundamental shift toward a mental health promotion and prevention paradigm transform not only help-seeking behaviour but also our broader conceptualisation of mental health and society's responsibility toward it?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: A paradigm shift toward mental health promotion and prevention would fundamentally reconceptualise mental health as a collective societal responsibility rather than an individual burden. Currently, our reactive, treatment-focused system places responsibility on individuals to recognise problems and navigate complex systems to get help. A promotion paradigm would position mental health like public health—where society invests in creating conditions for wellbeing, not just treating illness. This shift would mean: schools prioritising mental health literacy alongside academic learning; workplaces designing for psychological safety; urban planning considering mental health impacts; policy makers analysing mental health consequences of decisions. Help-seeking would become one strategy within a broader ecosystem of support, rather than the primary response to distress. Mental health would be understood as existing on a continuum where everyone benefits from promotion, rather than a binary of 'ill' and 'well'. This reconceptualisation challenges stigma by normalising mental health as part of human experience. It raises questions of social justice—if poor mental health is partly produced by inequality, poverty, and discrimination, then addressing these becomes mental health work. Ultimately, this paradigm recognises that the conditions for mental health are created collectively, and therefore responsibility for mental health must be shared.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Synthesises concepts to analyse paradigm shift implications for society, showing sophisticated reasoning about interconnections
